attributes.title: On the use of bots to decorrelate human judgments

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: On the use of opinion bots to decorrelate human collective judgments

other.value: Given that no similar studies have been carried out, we will also perform exploratory analysis to understand the nature of the phenomena under investigation

sample.value: We aim at testing a minimum of 15 groups (up to a maximum of 20 groups) per condition (random vs vae bot), which amounts to a total of N=300

analyses.value:
1. Generalized linear mixed effects models on the dependent variables with predictors condition and time
2. direct comparison between final group accuracy in the two conditions (eg t-test)
3. direct comparison between individual level and source level aggregation performance in the two conditions (eg t-test)

outliers.value:
- We intend to report analyses for all groups tested. However, our experimental manipulation might be extremely sensitive to idle participants. 
- For this reason, on top of all data analysis and to understand the upper boundary of the effects under investigation, analysis will also be performed following the exclusion criteria listed below:
1. removal of idle participants or participants who did not learn the underlying information functions
2. removal of groups containing idle participants or participants who did not learn the underlying information functions 

These criteria are set to 'clean the data' from variables that can pollute our effects of interest. 

-To avoid the issues related with the arbitrary exclusion of data points, we will include in our analysis confounding factors as covariates (eg whether people's learned the underlying information functions, whether they where idles, etc.)

dependent.value:
we will measure the following dependent variables:
1. individual accuracy (pre- and post- social interaction) measured in Brier scores 
2. group's accuracy (pre- and post- social interaction) measured in Brier scores using different aggregation rules: 
2a. mean/median
2b. max confidence
2c. individual level aggregation 
2d. source level aggregation
2e. bounded sum
3. social influence, expressed by the distance between pre and post social interaction predictions

conditions.value:
Individuals will be randomly assigned to 2 group conditions: 
(A) random bot. The bot will express random judgments in the social part of the experiment
(B) VAE bot. The bot will express judgements that favor minority views (ie. sampling closer to the centroid of the smaller cluster in vae latent space)

hypothesis.value:
Motivation: the 'wisdom of crowds' effect and many other collective intelligence phenomena are based on the assumption that individual judgments are independent from each other. This assumption is often not realized in many situations in realistic environments, where individuals often rely on the same information sources. If people rely on overlapping information sources, simple aggregation rules (eg mean and median) will distort aggregated judgements toward sources that are shared by a majority of individuals. 

Hypotheses: 
(H1) individuals will learn over time the relationship between their information source and the outcome variable 
(H2) Based on the correlation of judgments across individuals, a variational autoencoder should be able to create a low dimensional representation of individuals sharing similar information.
(H3) A clustering algorithm (operating either on raw data or on the VAE latent space) should be able to recover independent information sources underlying people's judgments.
(H4) Aggregating at the source level rather than at the individual level will improve predictive performance 
(H5) As VAE can also be used as generative models, we can devise a bot that has access to the low dimensional representation of people's information, and sample from this latent space so that its predictions are aligned with a specific cluster groups (e.g. the minority group) 
(H6) in an environment where independent sources are equally predictive of the final outcome, the deployment of such bot supporting minority views in the group will improve collective performance (compared to a randomly guessing bot)

2b. max confidence

2e. bounded sum
3. social influence, expressed by the distance between pre and post social interaction predictions

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: We will collect data from 100 participants. This sample size was determined by power analysis.

analyses.value: T-Tests for mean comparison between conditions.

outliers.value: Participants who are not students or native German speakers are excluded from the survey.

dependent.value: The dependent variables are attitudes towards people with migration background, threat and contact readiness. They will be measured with a questionnaire.

conditions.value: There are two conditions: multiculturalism vs. color-blindness. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the two conditions.

hypothesis.value: The aim of this work is to examine the influence of multiculturalism vs. color blindness on attitudes towards people with a migration background. The study is a conceptual replication of Richeson and Nussbaum (2004, JESP).

attributes.title: Creating Nonbelieved Memories for Bizarre Actions Using an Imagination Inflation Procedure

summary.value: The current experiments examined the creation of nonbelieved true and false memories after imagining bizarre and familiar actions using the imagination inflation procedure. In both experiments, participants took part in three sessions. In Session 1, participants had to perform or imagine simple familiar actions (e.g., "stir the water with the spoon") and bizarre actions (e.g., "balance the spoon on your nose"). A day later, participants needed to imagine simple actions of which some were new actions, and some were old actions that appeared in the first session. After a week, the participants completed a recognition task. For those actions that were correctly or incorrectly remembered as having been performed, the participant was challenged that the action was not performed  in order to evoke nonbelieved true and false memories. In general, we found that the imagination inflation procedure can successfully induce participants to produce nonbelieved memories.

registration_responses.summary: The current experiments examined the creation of nonbelieved true and false memories after imagining bizarre and familiar actions using the imagination inflation procedure. In both experiments, participants took part in three sessions. In Session 1, participants had to perform or imagine simple familiar actions (e.g., "stir the water with the spoon") and bizarre actions (e.g., "balance the spoon on your nose"). A day later, participants needed to imagine simple actions of which some were new actions, and some were old actions that appeared in the first session. After a week, the participants completed a recognition task. For those actions that were correctly or incorrectly remembered as having been performed, the participant was challenged that the action was not performed  in order to evoke nonbelieved true and false memories. In general, we found that the imagination inflation procedure can successfully induce participants to produce nonbelieved memories.

attributes.title: Thin Versus Overwheight women, same dehumanization ?
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

question2a.value:
We have three independent variables: 
-	Condition (control vs association retraining) : within-participants. 
-	Categories IAT targets (Thin woman vs Overweight woman) : between-participants
-	Words IAT categories (Animals vs Robots vs Human) : between-participants

There is an orthogonal relationship between them.

question2b.value: There is one dependent variable: Associations force (reaction time, difference between congruent and incongruent blocs, IAT effect)

question10b.value:
There are two tasks, a cognitive retraining task and two IAT. 
Associations retraining. For the first task, on the computer, the participants were in front of a procedure of associations retraining submitted in two distinct forms. The first form had 50% "thin-beautiful" associations and 50% "large-beautiful" associations. This procedure was dispensed to the control group. The second form included 25% thin-beautiful associations and 75% wide-beautiful associations. This second form was for the experimental group, it was the latter which represented the retraining procedure. At the beginning of the task, the age and sex of the participant were asked. This task has to be administered to all participants. 
A test of the procedure on a computer consisted of a combination such as "slim-beautiful" and "round-beautiful". Synonyms of these words were used, such as "Thin-Beautiful", "Large-Sexy" for each test.
Then we ask the participant through instructions explicitly written on the screen to perform a categorization task using two keys, the "E" key and the "I" key. When a combination of a word related to size and a word related to beauty appeared, they had to press the "I" key as soon as possible. We stated that the task lasted 5 to 10 minutes and we put a screen to remind the instructions before the participant presses the "Space" key to start. The associations are exchange on the screen at the middle of the task to avoid a learning phenomenon, we found them written such as "beautiful-thin" and "beautiful-round". We explain on the screen that the instructions are change and the participant have to press the "Space" key to continue. A screen is displayed at the end of this first computer task saying that the first task is over and that the participant has to call the experimenter who left the participant alone in the box.

IAT. The second task consisted of two computer IATs. A first Animal IAT and a second Machine IAT.
In the first IAT Animals we want to test the strength of the associations between each pair of concepts (thin or round women with photographs) and the pairs of attributes (human or animal traits). As for attributes, we take the words that the participants have to classify in the article by Bernard et al. (2014). The human words presented are moral, tradition, hair, foot and mouth. The animal words are nature, instinct, breeding, paw and snout. Bernard et al. chose the words describing the two different concepts with a pretest. Twenty participants gave their level of agreement with different words according to whether they were typical of animals or humans on a 9-point scale.
Pour finir, les deux IAT étaient composés de 7 blocs comme présentés dans la table 1. 
The photographs of women were taken from Assos website, an online clothing sales site, with a large size category. All the women in the photographs were taken on full feet, with the same postures and the same clothes (sweater and pants).
In the second IAT Machine we want to test the strength of associations between each concept pairs (overweight or slim women, with the same photographs) and attribute pairs (human or machine traits). For the human items they are the same as for the first IAT. For the machine items we will take them from Loughnan & Haslam (2007) who used words like android, artificial, automaton, computer, machine, mechanical, robot, synthetic in their study on the implicit associations between different social and non-human categories.
Finally, the two IATs will be composed of 7 blocks.




Composition of the two IATs, based on Greenwald, Mc Ghee & Schwartz (1998) : 
-	Block 1 (20 trials): Discrimination in the target category with Photographs of slim and plump women.
-	Block 2 (20 trials): Discrimination of the attribute category with Human attributes (IAT Machine and Animals) vs animals (IAT animals) vs machine (IAT Machine)
-	Block 3 (20 trials): Initial combined categorization with for IAT Animals Target presentation Round and Animal attribute VS Thin target and human attribute. And for IAT Machine  Thin target presentation and Machine attribute VS round target and Human attribute
-	Block 4 (40 trials): Initial combined categorization with for IAT Animals  Target presentation Round and Animal attribute VS Thin target and human attribute. And for IAT Machine  Thin target presentation and Machine attribute VS round target and Human attribute.
-	Block 5 (20 or 40 trials):  Discrimination overturned target category with reverse of thin and round categories of block 1 on the right and left of the screen
-	Block 6 (20 trials): Discrimination combined category reversed with reverse of the associations on the right and left of the screen of blocks 3 and 4.
-	Block 7 (40 trials) : Discrimination combined category reversed with reverse of the associations on the right and left of the screen of blocks 3 and 4.

Procedure. The participant will be received in an experimental box, the exact nature of the experience, which is the work on dehumanization, will not be revealed to the participant. After reading the information sheet and signing the consent forms, the participant will be in front of the computer screen. He will first read the instructions related to the retraining task, then performed the task. Following this first task, the participant will perform the second task, the two IAT, on the computer as well. This will end when the participant will have completed the IAT tests. Explanations will be then given to the participants on the nature of the experience, thanks will be presented for participating in the experience and the participant's experience sheet signed.

question4b.value: Participants have to be age 18. They are selected by course credits, they will be in the first year of Psychology Licence.

question5b.value: Data will be collected from participant answers from the IAT program on the computer (that are situated in an experimental box of the laboratory MSHS). They will be collected in a file from the program after each participant contribution. And each file will be kept with a USB key.

question7b.value: Data collection termination will be when we will reach the numbered of needed participants.

question1a.value:
1. The participants of control group (with the control retraining) will be faster to answer on the congruent blocs of the IAT with thin and mechanistic associations than the experimental group participants (with the experimental retraining). 
2. The participants of control group (with the control retraining) will be faster to answer on the congruent blocs of the IAT with overweight and animalist associations than the experimental group participants (with the experimental retraining).

question2a.value: There are two expected shape of interactions, one for each IAT. For the Animal IAT we expect less dehumanization of overweight women in retraining condition in comparison of control condition. And we expect no change in thin women dehumanization in the two condition groups. For the Robot IAT we expect less dehumanization for thin women in the retraining group than in control group. And we expect no changes for overweight women dehumanization in the comparison of the two condition groups.

question3a.value:
Manipulation should be needed to check if the retraining procedure have changed the associations, with an third IAT at the end of the two first. This IAT should check if the association between thin and beauty has changed. But we can see in scientific literature articles that explain uselessness of manipulation check. 
This check will not appear in our study because of time, we don’t have enough time to do it correctly. And, in the same time, because of the fact that this check should be in place at the end of the experimentation for each participant, the effect of associations modification can be over. 
But we can notice that in another study (of Leila Selimbegovic) which is not published for now, the same procedure has been used, but for a belief IAT (to be beautiful you have to be thin). In this study, the retraining have change the associations.

question5a.value:
The study of Loughnan and Haslam (2007) shows that the social perception of others can be incorporated in two different ways of dehumanization (animalistic and mechanistic). With a Go/NoGo Task they found that different social categories (artists and business people) are in an implicit way associated to two sorts of non-human objects (animals and robots). The congruent associations were stronger than the incongruent associations. 
We can see that there are two forms of dehumanization and that it is possible that these two forms can be linked to implicit associations (which is linked to social perception). We can think that social perception of thin and overweight women are different and that they can lead to two different sorts of dehumanization for these two types of woman. 
Bernard, Nathalie and Klein (2014) worked on the link between dehumanization and obesity stereotypes. Participants categorized more the images with overweight faces to animal characteristics than human characteristics. And thin faces were less categorized with animal characteristics than overweight faces. The authors said that the perception of obesity can be linked with animalistic dehumanization. People dehumanized obese people with negative animalization. 
In another way, if we take the study of Holland and Haslam (2013) which showed that thin woman are more objectified (Loughnan et al. (2010) ; Vaes, Paladino, & Puvia (2011) said that when participants bring their attention on woman’s body appearance, they give less mental state, moral status and less competences, humanity) than overweight women.
With these studies we can ask ourselves of thin women are dehumanized in a mechanistic ways and overweight women in an animalistic way.

question1c.value: Comparison of response times to the two IATs (aminals and robots) for the control group and the retraining group. Calculated by the computer.

question2c.value:
ANOVA will be conducted on JASP software. 
2(Condition : control or retraining) x2(Target category: Thin, Overweight) x 3(Target trait : human, animal, robot)  mixed ANOVAs, with as target morphology and target trait as repeated measures.
Comparisons will be calculated with a Bonferroni correction.

question3c.value:
DV : sort of dehumanization (animalistic, mechanistic). 
IVs : retraining, target category and target trait.

With these studies we can ask ourselves of thin women are dehumanized in a mechanistic ways and overweight women in an animalistic way.

There are two tasks, a cognitive retraining task and two IAT.

Then we ask the participant through instructions explicitly written on the screen to perform a categorization task using two keys, the "E" key and the "I" key. In the first IAT Animals we want to test the strength of the associations between each pair of concepts (thin or round women with photographs) and the pairs of attributes (human or animal traits). The animal words are nature, instinct, breeding, paw and snout. Bernard et al. chose the words describing the two different concepts with a pretest. Twenty participants gave their level of agreement with different words according to whether they were typical of animals or humans on a 9-point scale.
Pour finir, les deux IAT étaient composés de 7 blocs comme présentés dans la table 1. 
The photographs of women were taken from Assos website, an online clothing sales site, with a large size category. All the women in the photographs were taken on full feet, with the same postures and the same clothes (sweater and pants).
In the second IAT Machine we want to test the strength of associations between each concept pairs (overweight or slim women, with the same photographs) and attribute pairs (human or machine traits). For the human items they are the same as for the first IAT. For the machine items we will take them from Loughnan & Haslam (2007) who used words like android, artificial, automaton, computer, machine, mechanical, robot, synthetic in their study on the implicit associations between different social and non-human categories.
Finally, the two IATs will be composed of 7 blocks.




Composition of the two IATs, based on Greenwald, Mc Ghee & Schwartz (1998) : 
-	Block 1 (20 trials): Discrimination in the target category with Photographs of slim and plump women.
-	Block 2 (20 trials): Discrimination of the attribute category with Human attributes (IAT Machine and Animals) vs animals (IAT animals) vs machine (IAT Machine)
-	Block 3 (20 trials): Initial combined categorization with for IAT Animals Target presentation Round and Animal attribute VS Thin target and human attribute. And for IAT Machine  Thin target presentation and Machine attribute VS round target and Human attribute
-	Block 4 (40 trials): Initial combined categorization with for IAT Animals  Target presentation Round and Animal attribute VS Thin target and human attribute. And for IAT Machine  Thin target presentation and Machine attribute VS round target and Human attribute.
-	Block 5 (20 or 40 trials):  Discrimination overturned target category with reverse of thin and round categories of block 1 on the right and left of the screen
-	Block 6 (20 trials): Discrimination combined category reversed with reverse of the associations on the right and left of the screen of blocks 3 and 4.
-	Block 7 (40 trials) : Discrimination combined category reversed with reverse of the associations on the right and left of the screen of blocks 3 and 4.

Procedure. The participant will be received in an experimental box, the exact nature of the experience, which is the work on dehumanization, will not be revealed to the participant. After reading the information sheet and signing the consent forms, the participant will be in front of the computer screen. He will first read the instructions related to the retraining task, then performed the task. registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi: Comparison of response times to the two IATs (aminals and robots) for the control group and the retraining group. Calculated by the computer.

ANOVA will be conducted on JASP software. 
2(Condition : control or retraining) x2(Target category: Thin, Overweight) x 3(Target trait : human, animal, robot)  mixed ANOVAs, with as target morphology and target trait as repeated measures.
Comparisons will be calculated with a Bonferroni correction.

DV : sort of dehumanization (animalistic, mechanistic). 
IVs : retraining, target category and target trait.
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: Participants have to be age 18. They are selected by course credits, they will be in the first year of Psychology Licence.

Data will be collected from participant answers from the IAT program on the computer (that are situated in an experimental box of the laboratory MSHS). They will be collected in a file from the program after each participant contribution. And each file will be kept with a USB key.
Data collection termination will be when we will reach the numbered of needed participants.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Gist-guided attention: The effects of gist-absent vs. gist-present image previews on visual search.

other.value:
We may study the effects of repetition on RT by comparing sets of trials grouped into ‘bins’. The width of these bins (i.e., number of trials included in each of bin) will be varied to identify to best capture learning dynamics. For instance, the first and second halves of trials may be compared, or changes between every twenty trials may be compared.
Additionally, we will study changes in response accuracy over trial repetitions, though RT will remain the primary effect of interest.

sample.value: From a review of related studies, and a power analysis of the pilot data, we have determined that our sample size will be 32 participants.

analyses.value: We will use a linear mixed-effects regression model with Bayesian estimation as our primary method of analysis. We will model log-transformed RT as predicted by fixed effects for trial repetition (i.e., number of trial repetitions split by category), scene category, preview type, and their interaction. Random effects will include participant, trial repetition and category. A model comparison approach will be leveraged to select which random effects should be included in the statistical models opting. The incorporation of the log transform and Bayes estimator serves to account for the skewness inherent to measures of RT (Matzke, Dolan, Logan, Brown, & Wagenmakers, 2013) and to relax the normality assumptions of linear regression.

outliers.value: A participant’s data will be excluded if their response accuracy is less than 85%.

dependent.value: The key dependent variable is response time (RT), where RT is assumed to be a sufficient analog for visual search efficiency (Wolfe, Alvarez, Rosenholtz, Kuzmova, & Sherman, 2011). Specifically, we will measure the amount of time from search display onset until participants make a correct target detection. We intend to observe if, and how, RT transforms with gained experience in the visual search task over trials, and if, and how, RT transforms with the presence of scene gist in the search preview.

conditions.value: There are two conditions based on preview type: intact and phase-scrambled. Participants will concurrently complete tasks in both conditions. There will be ninety trials in each condition, where each trial lasts up to ten seconds, depending on the speed of participants’ responses. Participants will receive an equal number of each type of preview in each type of scene category image, and comparisons will be made within-subjects.

hypothesis.value: Can scene gist and its associated vast semantic knowledge be flexibly, and usefully, used in new learning? We hypothesize that participants’ visual search strategies will become more efficient (faster target detection) after repeatedly experiencing search targets located in positions unique to scene categories with progressing trials, such that they are able to identify a target in an image more quickly based on the scene’s category. Moreover, it is expected that visual search will be more efficient when the same search image, rather than a phase-scrambled version of the search image (scene gist is absent), is used as a preview.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.
registration_responses.name: Gist-guided attention: The effects of gist-absent vs. gist-present image previews on visual search.
registration_responses.other:
We may study the effects of repetition on RT by comparing sets of trials grouped into ‘bins’. The width of these bins (i.e., number of trials included in each of bin) will be varied to identify to best capture learning dynamics. For instance, the first and second halves of trials may be compared, or changes between every twenty trials may be compared.
Additionally, we will study changes in response accuracy over trial repetitions, though RT will remain the primary effect of interest.
registration_responses.sample: From a review of related studies, and a power analysis of the pilot data, we have determined that our sample size will be 32 participants.
registration_responses.analyses: We will use a linear mixed-effects regression model with Bayesian estimation as our primary method of analysis. We will model log-transformed RT as predicted by fixed effects for trial repetition (i.e., number of trial repetitions split by category), scene category, preview type, and their interaction. Random effects will include participant, trial repetition and category. A model comparison approach will be leveraged to select which random effects should be included in the statistical models opting. The incorporation of the log transform and Bayes estimator serves to account for the skewness inherent to measures of RT (Matzke, Dolan, Logan, Brown, & Wagenmakers, 2013) and to relax the normality assumptions of linear regression.
registration_responses.outliers: A participant’s data will be excluded if their response accuracy is less than 85%.
registration_responses.dependent: The key dependent variable is response time (RT), where RT is assumed to be a sufficient analog for visual search efficiency (Wolfe, Alvarez, Rosenholtz, Kuzmova, & Sherman, 2011). Specifically, we will measure the amount of time from search display onset until participants make a correct target detection. We intend to observe if, and how, RT transforms with gained experience in the visual search task over trials, and if, and how, RT transforms with the presence of scene gist in the search preview.
registration_responses.conditions: There are two conditions based on preview type: intact and phase-scrambled. Participants will concurrently complete tasks in both conditions. There will be ninety trials in each condition, where each trial lasts up to ten seconds, depending on the speed of participants’ responses. Participants will receive an equal number of each type of preview in each type of scene category image, and comparisons will be made within-subjects.
registration_responses.hypothesis: Can scene gist and its associated vast semantic knowledge be flexibly, and usefully, used in new learning? We hypothesize that participants’ visual search strategies will become more efficient (faster target detection) after repeatedly experiencing search targets located in positions unique to scene categories with progressing trials, such that they are able to identify a target in an image more quickly based on the scene’s category. Moreover, it is expected that visual search will be more efficient when the same search image, rather than a phase-scrambled version of the search image (scene gist is absent), is used as a preview.

data.value: Yes, we already collected the data.

name.value: Partisan Prosociality Full Study - Fall 2019, with exploratory data

other.value: After the main study was completed, we also had all participants complete the study in the other role: Participants initially assigned to the task engagement condition completed the prediction conditions, and those in the task prediction condition completed the engagement conditions. This data was collected for purposes of exploratory analysis.

sample.value: We collected data until we reached 280 participants; this target N was reached via a power analysis conducted with PANGEA (Westfall, 2016: jakewestfall.org/pangea/) on two pilot studies collected in our lab.

analyses.value:
Primary analysis: 2 x 3 between-subjects ANOVA on amount of effort: 2 (task: engagement vs. prediction) x 3 (partisan relationship: co-partisan, counter-partisan, control). Because partisan relationship is a within-subjects factor for prediction participants, we will use only the first predictions participants made in our initial analyses. We will conduct this same model controlling for attitudes toward helping others (AHO), attitudes toward charitable organizations (ACO), and gender. We will also conduct these two models using percent of task completed as the dependent variable. 
Follow-up analyses: To follow-up our primary analyses, we will conduct focused contrast tests. We will determine the simple effect of task type (engagement vs. prediction) in each of the three partisanship conditions (co-partisan, counter-partisan, and control), both with and without the above-mentioned controls. We will also conduct a one-way ANCOVA assessing the effect of partisan relationship on predicted self-effort for participants in the prediction task condition, using AHO and ACO as controls. To conduct the between-by-within version of the primary 2 x 3 ANOVA, we will use bootstrapping in order to treat partisan relationship as fully within-subjects.

outliers.value: We will compute the overall mean and standard deviation of our DVs (time spent on task, percent of task completed) and treat any observations that are more than 2.5 SD above/below the mean as outliers. We will then conduct the analyses with and without outliers and report any changes in effects.

dependent.value: Effort expended during the charitable task. For participants actually engaging in the task, effort will be assessed through: 1. Time spent doing task; and 2. Percent of task completed. For participants making predictions about their performance in this task, predicted effort will be assessed through: 1. Predicted amount of time spent on the task in each conditions; and 2. Predicted number of questions completed correctly.

conditions.value: 15 conditions in a mixed design lab study. Participants were initially assigned to one of two task conditions: engagement vs. prediction (2 between-subjects conditions). Partisan condition is between-subjects for participants in the engagement condition, and within-subjects for participants in the prediction condition: Participants in the task engagement condition are randomly assigned to partisan condition (Democratic, Republican, or control; 3 between-subjects conditions); and participants in the prediction condition make predictions about people all three partisan conditions (Democratic, Republican, and control; 3 within-subject conditions). Prediction condition participants will make a further three predictions about how they themselves would perform in all three partisan conditions (Democratic, Republican, and control; 3 within-subjects conditions).

hypothesis.value: Partisan-affiliated participants will predict that they will be more strongly influenced by partisan cues during an effortful task for charity than they are when actually engaging in the task.

registration_responses.data: Yes, we already collected the data.
registration_responses.name: Partisan Prosociality Full Study - Fall 2019, with exploratory data
registration_responses.other: After the main study was completed, we also had all participants complete the study in the other role: Participants initially assigned to the task engagement condition completed the prediction conditions, and those in the task prediction condition completed the engagement conditions. registration_responses.sample: We collected data until we reached 280 participants; this target N was reached via a power analysis conducted with PANGEA (Westfall, 2016: jakewestfall.org/pangea/) on two pilot studies collected in our lab.

To conduct the between-by-within version of the primary 2 x 3 ANOVA, we will use bootstrapping in order to treat partisan relationship as fully within-subjects.

We will then conduct the analyses with and without outliers and report any changes in effects.

attributes.title: Feminism, gender inequality perception and economic inequality perception

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value:
Feminism and economic inequality perception. Exploratory analyses of the relation between feminist ideology and non-explicit feminist activism.

This study aims to determine if there are any relationships established among feminism and the perception of economic inequality and collective actions against this inequality. Correlational and regression analyses will be conducted. In addition, some demographic variables (subjective social class, age, sex, sexual orientation) will be controlled.

other.value:
Demographic variables (subjective socioeconomic class, age, sex, nationality and sexual orientation) will be controlled 

additional mediation and moderation analysis would be done.

sample.value: A minimum of 200 valid observations will be collected. This may allow us to achieve a statistical power ≥ .80, considering an α = .05 and a f2 = .05. Data collection will take place from 13th January and it will stop on 17th January or when we will reach 300 observations (after exclusions), whichever comes first.

analyses.value: Correlational analyses and regression analyses will be conducted to test our hypothesis .

outliers.value: Questionnaires fulfilled by non-Spaniards participants and/or participants less than 18 years old will be excluded from the analyses.

dependent.value:
- Feminism: measured with the "Knowledge and attitudes toward feminism" scale pruposed by García, Cala & Trigo Sánchez (2016). 
- Economic inequality perception: measured with the “Perception of economic inequality in everyday life – PEIEL” scale (García-Castro, Willis &. Rodríguez-Bailón, 2019).
- Collective actions to reduce economic inequality: measured with an adaptation from the scale used by Jiménez-Moya (2014).

conditions.value: There will be one single condition for all participants in this study.

hypothesis.value:
This study aims to explore if there are any relationships established among feminism and the perception of economic inequality or other variables associated to this inequality such as support to collective actions to reduce it.
H1: Feminism will correlate positively with economic inequality perception. 
H2: Feminism will correlate positively with support to collective actions.
H3: Economic inequality perception will correlate positively with support to collective actions.
H4: Feminism will have influence over the measured variables (economic inequality perception and collective actions).

attributes.title: Feminism, gender inequality perception and economic inequality perception

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value:
Feminism and gender inequality perception. Exploratory analyses and proposal of new measurements.

This study aims to determine if there are any relationships established among feminist beliefs and the perception of gender inequality. In order to explore this, a proposal of a gender inequality perception measure has been developed. Also other variables such as collective actions  men’s collective interests and general attitudes toward affirmative actions will be measured. Correlational and regression analyses will be conducted. In addition, some demographic variables (subjective social class, age, sex, sexual orientation) will be controlled.

other.value:
Demographic variables (subjective socioeconomic class, age, sex, nationality and sexual orientation) will be controlled 

Additional mediation and moderation analyses will be done.


This prerregistration was published before data collection has finished. No analyses have been conducted or will be conducted before 13th January or untill we reach 360 observations.

sample.value: A minimum of 260 valid observations will be collected. This may allow us to achieve a statistical power ≥ .80, considering a α = .05 and a f2 = .05. Data collection will take place from 9th January and it will stop on 13th January or when we will reach 360 observations (after exclusions), whichever comes first.

analyses.value: Correlational analyses and regression analyses will be conducted to test our hypothesis.

outliers.value: Questionnaires fulfilled by non-Spaniards participants and/or participants less than 18 years old will be excluded from the analyses.

dependent.value:
- Feminism: measured with the "Knowledge and attitudes toward feminism" scale pruposed by  García, Cala & Trigo Sánchez (2016). 
- Gender inequality perception: measured with a 31 items scale developed for this study.
- Collective actions to reduce gender inequality: measured with an adaptation from the scale used by Jiménez-Moya (2014).
-  Attitudes toward affirmative actions: measured with Moya & Expósito (2001) version of the "Attitudes toward affirmative action scale" (Tougas, Brown, Beaton & Joly, 1995).
- Men's collective interest: measured with Moya & Expósito (2001) version of the "Men's collective interest scale" (Tougas, Brown, Beaton & Joly, 1995).

conditions.value: There will be one single condition for all participants.

hypothesis.value:
This study aims to explore if there are any relationships established among feminism and the perception of gender inequality or other variables associated to this inequality such as: support to collective actions, attitudes towards affirmative actions and men's collective interest.
H1: Feminism will correlate positively with gender inequality perception. 
H2: Feminism will correlate positively with support to collective actions.
H3: Gender inequality perception will correlate positively with support to collective actions.
H4: Gender inequality perception will correlate positively with attitudes towards affirmative action.
H5: Gender inequality perception will correlate negatively with men’s collective interest. 
H6: Feminism will have influence over the measured variables (inequality gender perception, collective actions, attitudes toward affirmative action and men’s collective interest).

registration_responses.data: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.
registration_responses.name:

In order to explore this, a proposal of a gender inequality perception measure has been developed. Also other variables such as collective actions  men’s collective interests and general attitudes toward affirmative actions will be measured. Correlational and regression analyses will be conducted. In addition, some demographic variables (subjective social class, age, sex, sexual orientation) will be controlled.

- Feminism: measured with the "Knowledge and attitudes toward feminism" scale pruposed by  García, Cala & Trigo Sánchez (2016). 
- Gender inequality perception: measured with a 31 items scale developed for this study.
- Collective actions to reduce gender inequality: measured with an adaptation from the scale used by Jiménez-Moya (2014).
-  Attitudes toward affirmative actions: measured with Moya & Expósito (2001) version of the "Attitudes toward affirmative action scale" (Tougas, Brown, Beaton & Joly, 1995).
- Men's collective interest: measured with Moya & Expósito (2001) version of the "Men's collective interest scale" (Tougas, Brown, Beaton & Joly, 1995).
registration_responses.conditions: There will be one single condition for all participants.
registration_responses.hypothesis:
This study aims to explore if there are any relationships established among feminism and the perception of gender inequality or other variables associated to this inequality such as: support to collective actions, attitudes towards affirmative actions and men's collective interest.
H1: Feminism will correlate positively with gender inequality perception. 
H2: Feminism will correlate positively with support to collective actions.
H3: Gender inequality perception will correlate positively with support to collective actions.
H4: Gender inequality perception will correlate positively with attitudes towards affirmative action.
H5: Gender inequality perception will correlate negatively with men’s collective interest. 
H6: Feminism will have influence over the measured variables (inequality gender perception, collective actions, attitudes toward affirmative action and men’s collective interest).

summary.value: Updated sampling plan for "Position Effects in the Sequential Lineup" registration https://osf.io/3v2p6.

attributes.title: Methods of Spontaneous Breathing Trial for weaning from mechanical ventilation in adults: A Network Meta-analysis

q1.value: Methods of Spontaneous Breathing Trial for weaning from mechanical ventilation in adults: A Network Meta-analysis

q2.value: Hong-Jie Jhou, Po-Huang Chen, Ou-Yang Liang Jun, Wei-Ting Yen, Chin Lin, Cho-Hao Lee, Shih-En Tang

q3.value: Although several systematic review and meta-analysis had evaluated different ventilator mode by the pairwise comparisons of liberation from mechanical ventilation, no study has presented a head-to-head comparison of the efficacy of the different mode to perform a spontaneous breathing trial in patients with mechanical ventilation. Therefore, we conducted this network meta-analysis to assess the relative efficacy of each technique with the aim of providing treatment recommendations to physicians in daily clinical practice.

q4.value: This network meta-analysis to assess the relative efficacy of each technique with the aim of providing treatment recommendations to physicians in daily clinical practice.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Network meta-analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: gistration prior to accessing the data

question.value: A researcher with a health economic background (CL) designed and performed a comprehensive search without language restrictions using PubMed, Embase, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, Baidu Scholar (www.xueshu.baidu.com), and the Web of Science from inception until November 01 2019, to identify all relevant trials with screening the titles and reviewing the abstracts. In order to ensure that no RCTs were missing, gray literature was searched, reference lists of included articles were reviewed, and searches were conducted using Google Scholar, the US government clinical trials database (www.ClinicalTrials.gov) and the UK National Research Register.

q13.value:
31 randomized controlled trials met the inclusion criteria and included a total of 5,217
patients with mechanical ventilator in the intensive care unit.

q14.value: We did a network meta-analysis using a frequentist approach and provided a point estimate from the network and a 95% CI from the frequency distribution of the estimate. All network meta-analyses were done with the statistical package “netmeta” 0.9-0 (https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/netmeta/index.html) in R 3.4.2 (R Core Team, Vienna, Austria) and Stata, version 14 (Stata Corp, College Station, Texas).

question.value:
1.	Weaning success deﬁned as the absence of the requirement for invasive MV support, without reintubation, no cardiac arrest event or mortality for 48 hours after extubation (translaryngeal tube) or withdrawal (tracheostomy tube), or as deﬁned by study authors.
2.	Proportion requiring reintubation (defined as the patient requiring reintubation in 48 hours after extubation, or as deﬁned by study authors).
3.	Mortality (Hospital mortality, or as deﬁned by study authors).

We produced a pooled odds risk (OR) with 95% conﬁdence intervals (CI) to summarize the effect of each comparison tested using a random-effects model as a conservative estimate. For pooling the continuous data, we calculated the mean difference (MD) with 95% confidence intervals (CIs). For dichotomous variables such as mortality, we deleted the trials with zero events in all arms of each outcome. As a result, there was no imputation for zero cell counts performed.
The probability of a mode being ranked was calculated as their surface under cumulative ranking curve (SUCRA), which is the percentage of efficacy achieved by an approach compared with an imaginary approach that is always the best without uncertainty (ie, SUCRA 100%). SUCRA provides a hierarchy of treatments and accounts for variance of all relative intervention effects. Higher SUCRA scores correspond to greater weaning success rate or lower proportion requiring reintubation and mortality. Forest plots represent the results of NMA and summary relative mean effects, 95% confidence intervals and SUCRA for all comparisons together. The results of SUCRA were summarized with all interventions and outcomes in a rank-heat plot.

We did a network meta-analysis using a frequentist approach and provided a point estimate from the network and a 95% CI from the frequency distribution of the estimate. All network meta-analyses were done with the statistical package “netmeta” 0.9-0 (https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/netmeta/index.html) in R 3.4.2 (R Core Team, Vienna, Austria) and Stata, version 14 (Stata Corp, College Station, Texas).
 We examined the symmetry and geometry of the evidence by producing a network plot with node for the number of study subjects and connection size corresponding to the number of studies. The contribution of each direct comparison to the estimation of the network summary effects was calculated according to the combination of the variance of the direct treatment effect and the network structure.
In order to include all studies within one framework and prevent lower precision of estimating effect size, we chose “lumping treatments” designs and made an assumption that no difference in efficacy due to clinical setting of ventilatory inspiratory pressure or Positive end expiratory pressure (eg. PSV with pressure 8 mmHg vs. 5 mmHg).

q21.value: The quality of evidence derived from the network meta-analysis was judged by use of the GRADE framework. In this approach, first of all, both quality of direct and indirect evidence should be assessed separately. If randomised trials form the evidence, the direct evidence rating starts at high quality and can be down rating by the concern of risk of bias, inconsistency, indirectness, imprecision, or publication bias. The rating of indirect evidence began with the lower evidence rating of the two pairwise direct comparisons of first-order loops, but can be rated down further for imprecision or intransitivity (differences between studies that form the basis for the indirect evidence in clinical or methodological characteristics). After that, when both direct and indirect evidence are available, higher of the two quality ratings was suggested by GRADE Working Group for rating of quality of NMA effect estimates.

q22.value: We excluded trials that evaluated: neonatal or pediatrics patients; postoperative adult patients (following cardiac surgery, neurosurgery etc.); trials that extubated patients directly to noninvasive ventilation for the purpose of weaning; trials that comparing conducting SBT to no SBT; trials that comparing same ventilation mode but different parameters..

q23.value: This will depend of the chosen scenario, as detailed previously.

q24.value: Subgroup analyses were conducted based on the following effect modiﬁers: endotracheal prosthesis, publication year before and after 2008, and patients with COPD. Comparison-adjusted funnel plots and the Egger’s test were also assessed for publication bias or other small study effects for all available interventions of NMA.

In order to ensure that no RCTs were missing, gray literature was searched, reference lists of included articles were reviewed, and searches were conducted using Google Scholar, the US government clinical trials database (www.ClinicalTrials.gov) and the UK National Research Register.
registration_responses.q17.question:
1.	Weaning success deﬁned as the absence of the requirement for invasive MV support, without reintubation, no cardiac arrest event or mortality for 48 hours after extubation (translaryngeal tube) or withdrawal (tracheostomy tube), or as deﬁned by study authors.
2.	Proportion requiring reintubation (defined as the patient requiring reintubation in 48 hours after extubation, or as deﬁned by study authors).
3.	Mortality (Hospital mortality, or as deﬁned by study authors).
registration_responses.q18.question:
We produced a pooled odds risk (OR) with 95% conﬁdence intervals (CI) to summarize the effect of each comparison tested using a random-effects model as a conservative estimate. For pooling the continuous data, we calculated the mean difference (MD) with 95% confidence intervals (CIs). For dichotomous variables such as mortality, we deleted the trials with zero events in all arms of each outcome. As a result, there was no imputation for zero cell counts performed.
The probability of a mode being ranked was calculated as their surface under cumulative ranking curve (SUCRA), which is the percentage of efficacy achieved by an approach compared with an imaginary approach that is always the best without uncertainty (ie, SUCRA 100%). SUCRA provides a hierarchy of treatments and accounts for variance of all relative intervention effects. Higher SUCRA scores correspond to greater weaning success rate or lower proportion requiring reintubation and mortality. Forest plots represent the results of NMA and summary relative mean effects, 95% confidence intervals and SUCRA for all comparisons together. The results of SUCRA were summarized with all interventions and outcomes in a rank-heat plot.
registration_responses.q19.question:
We did a network meta-analysis using a frequentist approach and provided a point estimate from the network and a 95% CI from the frequency distribution of the estimate. All network meta-analyses were done with the statistical package “netmeta” 0.9-0 (https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/netmeta/index.html) in R 3.4.2 (R Core Team, Vienna, Austria) and Stata, version 14 (Stata Corp, College Station, Texas).
 We examined the symmetry and geometry of the evidence by producing a network plot with node for the number of study subjects and connection size corresponding to the number of studies. The contribution of each direct comparison to the estimation of the network summary effects was calculated according to the combination of the variance of the direct treatment effect and the network structure.
In order to include all studies within one framework and prevent lower precision of estimating effect size, we chose “lumping treatments” designs and made an assumption that no difference in efficacy due to clinical setting of ventilatory inspiratory pressure or Positive end expiratory pressure (eg. PSV with pressure 8 mmHg vs. 5 mmHg).
